topic.title: ZeroBlog - Share your suggestions
topic.body:
I couldn't find any place for general suggestions regarding parts of ZeroNet instead of the whole network... so I hope this thread will be helpful.

My suggestion: add view permissions to the ZeroBlog template to be able to hide content or make it public.

topic.title: Looking for huge music collection!
topic.body:
I urgently need a huge music collection. Can be any trashy charts/garbage music. Important is that the collection is at least 450GB+ files in LOSSY formats. (NOT lossless .flac or .ape, etc.).

Ideally: 470GB+ of american/european charts that were released between the years 2010 and 2015.

topic.title: Zeronet should have its own
topic.body: browser. We could start with a pre-configured version of Tor Browser, which has JavaScript enabled, localhost white-listed, etc. Then add the function that every time you put in a .bit address into the address bar then it will automatically speak to 127.0.0.1:43110/test.bit instead of only test.bit.

topic.title: Looking for crypto mining advice
topic.body:
I would like some opinions from people who have long time experience with the cryptocurrencies they mined. Regarding profitability, how reliable the network is, what they learned from it, what they changed and do differently now. Starting with that, I want to see some recommendations on what really makes sense to mine right now, according to their opinions.
(I'm not interested in a generic profitabilit calculation á la whattomine.com...)

topic.title: Brainstorm Assistance for IT project
topic.body: Let's assume I have a friend that has "unlimited" (because it's free) supply of electrical power but very restricted and little internet access. I'd like to use that opportunity to put at least 1 computer in his room to do some CPU/GPU heavy stuff that normally wouldn't be doable in a home where you have to pay electricity. The first idea I had is of course mining cryptocurrencies but since the internet is so restricted, I would need to pay for a mobile internet access each month so if I would decide to do that then the mining should at least drop 30 bucks each month. That's why I wonder if anyone knows something as cool to do that is doable offline as well. I'd be happy about some inspiration.

> [rythyrix](#comment_71_18eGWSaM3Vc9i61LVfogjQJf5gp7EN7b9Y): Regarding favorited sites, ZeroNet stores your favorite zites as a JSON object inside your browser's local storage. According to this Superuser post, Firefox's cookie and local storage permissions are linked. First, check if your cookies are allowed for 127.0.0.1 and/or localhost and not wiped between closing all tabs/the window (hello, Self-Destructing Cookies addon, fancy seeing you here). This should fix the issue, but I've never experienced the problem, so YMMV. [...]

Thank you, very helpful.
By now I have another additional problem: some sites tell me e.g. "1 File update failed!". How do I fix this?

> [rythyrix](#comment_72_18eGWSaM3Vc9i61LVfogjQJf5gp7EN7b9Y): That's simply the fact that none of your peers you have connected (connected, not available, there's a difference) have that file, or the file was corrupted en route, or the peer sent a file with the wrong sum. Could be a number of things. Go to the zite that has that error, and drag the purple 0 at the top right leftward. Scroll down to 'Missing Files' and see what file it is. Chances are high it's a user's file, i.e. starting with data/users/ and no one has a correctly signed or summed copy. It happens, and as your connections refresh or swap between your peers, it should resolve itself unless zero people have valid copies.

Once again, thank you very much. I cloned the blog site and it says my `content.json` is missing. On 0mail 3 `users/` files are missing. But this persists since days. What can I do?

> [rythyrix](#comment_81_18eGWSaM3Vc9i61LVfogjQJf5gp7EN7b9Y): Check out the lovely @mkg20001's tutorial and prebuilt APKs. The prebuilt isn't secure for private keys or other sensitive data, at least not without root access and mountbinds, due to exposing the data directory and therefore users.json to USB file transfers (MTP). :( If you can, root your phone, not like OEMs will honor warranties anyway.

> [1491301186](#comment_21_1AZG3avnpwcn37q9eeCEjXKFBye81eAxg5): Even if you are using "Tor = Always" mode your real clearnet IP address may be leaked. To protect yourself from leaks you need to use a physical Tor router, like https://www.anonabox.com .

They don't use the newest IEEE standard, therefore the price is way to high considering the device is already technically "old" and not future proof. It might seem unnecessary now and maybe 1 or 2 years in the future, but not everyone can afford to buy this thing now and after two years again...

> [rythyrix](#comment_100_18eGWSaM3Vc9i61LVfogjQJf5gp7EN7b9Y): Looking at the all.js under ZeroID, line 886 begins a function to send a https POST request to https://demo.zeronet.io/ZeroID/request.php. Without your browser configured to use either a proxy or Tor, this request will be sent with your clearnet IP in its protocol header, enabling anyone with a packet sniffer on either your or the server's end to see where those packets were sent to/from. While the theoretical adversary cannot read the contents of the packets without breaking the encryption on the https stream, traffic correlation is a thing. [...]

Well explained theory, but this certainly doesn't apply to pragmatic reality for 99% of all users ever here. Nobody who would be able to make "1,000,000,000,000 guesses/sec." would waste this power to crack some average ZeroNet user's key. If someone is that important then they'd need to isolate themselves wholely anyway, which would already including procedures like the one you mentioned. But yes, in theory, you are completely right.

I got an urgent issue! Recently I edited one of my zites, then I got an error saying "Internal I/O Error", so I restarted the ZeroNet client. Then I had to realize that all my settings, saved zites, etc. were all deleted and reset! It looks like I am using ZeroNet for the first time when visiting ZeroHello. > [nofish](#comment_922_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): Do you have data/sites.json-tmpold or data/users.json-tmpold file? Also can see the error in log/debug-last.log?

Wow, thanks. I replaced sites.json with sites.json-tmpold and everything is back! It is really helpful, that the ZeroNet application has this function in case something breaks. Thanks again!

> [seequ](#comment_1_19BZ9s633TaM3t7oW5bQPTPQJU3cbyibVH): ZeroNet is wonderful tech. There's just one thing that keeps me slightly worried: a zite that I pass by might seem innocuous so I don't explicitly delete it. Maybe it was at that time and later they added illegal content - or maybe it always had illegal content and I didn't know about it. Anyways, because I would now be sharing illegal content, I'd be liable.I wish sharing was opt-in, rather than opt-out, and that the UI neatly displayed all files the zite has before you choose to host it.

It would be horrible for the network, if sharing was opt-in. Its better to leave it as opt-out so as many people as possible share as many zites as they can. Every single peer makes the network stronger. The less peers, the worse. And if you find a malicious zite, you can "Pause" the sharing for each site individually, as described below. That method is much better for the network. (Btw. I visited many zites already and didn't find even one that seemed bad to me...)

> [sirius17](#comment_2_1G6QESmeipZsukJX5WvDxxwSioaGnEDRk3): This is a very valid point and it worries me too. I'm not sure how to solve the problem of illegal / amoral content but perhaps some kind of warning system that would allow users to flag bad content.

That would weaken the purporse of a resilient decentralized network of strongly guarded free speech. Alternative zites would probably be down-flagged much more often and that would reduce their availability. And bam, we are back to the censorship of Twitter and Youtube. Why bother to use this network in the first place if such features would exist here, too?

2_1Cy1dDBGdk9AE6c2HbU97yXpxB29t1D16j.body:
> [prudence](#comment_3_1Cy1dDBGdk9AE6c2HbU97yXpxB29t1D16j): Is it just a matter of the site owner deleting the entry in one of the JSON files if they want to stop it from appearing to new users?

> [nofish](#comment_1018_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): After some time (30 tries) you client will give up on the unreachable files and they will disappear from your client.

No, that didn't happen.

I'll tell you now the real story. I got this problem since many months now. It is a huge bug in ZeroNet. Sadly the only thing that can fix this is re-installing your whole ZN folder and copying your personal ``users.json`` over to the new install dir. If you have your own zites, then you should copy their folder within your old ``data`` dir to the new one. Then you can either additionally copy the old ``sites.json`` to your new ``data`` folder, but that can cause other issues, as well. Therefore, to be completely safe, just copy the code from the old ``sites.json`` of your zite only to the new ``sites.json``. Then add ZeroTalk, etc. the same way again, as if you started ZN the first time.

> [nofish](#comment_1021_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): It should and does for me, but the counter was restarted if you restarted the client. I just did a modification that will keep the counter during the restarts. You can see the tries if you hover your mouse over the bad file on the sidebar.

At the worst time, which was recently, it even stacked up to over 100 files not updated on ZeroTalk e.g., which has more than enough seeders. This was crazy, so I re-installed everything and it works acceptable now.

> [nofish](#comment_1021_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): It should and does for me, but the counter was restarted if you restarted the client. I just did a modification that will keep the counter during the restarts. You can see the tries if you hover your mouse over the bad file on the sidebar.

It happens again! Since a week I have once again 4 update fails on ZeroMail and 1 on ZeroTalk. I was refreshing all pages at least a million times since then. It is 100% clear, that this solution does **not** work.

> [nofish](#comment_1028_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): It only retries every 10 minute, so it won't disappear immediately. You can see the retry times by hover over the missing file name on sidebar. (it will be deleted once it reaches 30)

I thought it deletes those requests after 30 refreshs.

> [nofish](#comment_1028_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): It only retries every 10 minute, so it won't disappear immediately. You can see the retry times by hover over the missing file name on sidebar. (it will be deleted once it reaches 30)

Okay, I see the retries, now. Thanks!
I can confirm now, it indeed works, after all.

> [helium](#comment_7_1Pv5CdXMDJm5k5iAp4SVbutnMg2ue8e58p): I don't speak Chinese either, but to call Chinese untidy is rude.How about me calling Your native language untidy?(English is not my native language.)

I'm pretty sure it was translated not completely correct. Nobody says that Chinese is _untidy_. The English FORUM is _untidy_ if all languages are mixed in here.

That said, you can say everything you want to say about my "native language". Freedom of speech OP.

> [helium](#comment_8_1Pv5CdXMDJm5k5iAp4SVbutnMg2ue8e58p): Well, I guess there is a need for an agreement, what languages are being used in a forum. So, I agree with You on that part. However, the world has so many different languages and none of us is able to learn all of them, so I think that the "airport rule" that English is accepted everywhere should also hold on internet forums. Many international companies have a rule that to make sure that nobody is feeling being left out, everybody speaks English or some other language that absolutely everyone at the given conversation can understand. If everybody in this forum were able to understand Chinese, then from that perspective it was OK for them to use Chinese, because nobody was left out, till I appeared.  [...]

Not really, no discussion needed. The main forum is English only. If one wants to talk in another language, just change the forum to its respective language in the language selection bar on the top of this zite. That does not mean, the English forum is worth more/the Chinese forum is worth less. It just means that each language has its own forum so people can better read and not be annoyed by languages, they don't understand. It's just an organization thing, not about power or supremacy.

> [helium](#comment_10_1Pv5CdXMDJm5k5iAp4SVbutnMg2ue8e58p): Thank You for the answer. I did not notice the language selection bar. At the presence of the language selection bar the selection from the bar is the agreement on language. On the other hand, I did not notice the bar before You mentioned it and may be the Chinese people did not notice the bar either. It's not an excuse for them to use Chinese at the English forum or vice a versa, but it does seem to be a usability design flaw. I consider the language matter decided: selection from the language bar determines the required language. [...]

Thank you for your kind response.

Actually I think that making big file seeding or any torrent-like file distribution a real part of the ZeroNet application structure is the wrong way. Why? Because every step in this direction makes ZeroNet less and less mobile. I prefer having a super slim ZeroNet with only the necessary files, so I can use it basically everywhere without having to manage missing big files I store only at one computer, for example.
Therefore I would suggest that any file sharing implementation is managed as separate as possible from the actual ZeroNet app. E.g. in this case I would totally recommend against putting anything like that into /data/user/ or any similar location.

(I know you could still use ZeroNet somewhere else without the files, but it makes it much more complicated. Also the deeper the implementation the weirder it gets for ZeroNet to stretch itself so drastically over several devices.)

@realkittykate To your original post: if you want to solve your current problem, you can just use ZFS. I wrote a tutorial on how to get started on it. This way all HDDs you use count as one volume, without borders, at all.

> [krixano](#comment_110_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): Why would you have to manage the missing big files? You don't need those big files on every device you use. If you want just necessary files, then don't use big files. It doesn't make it more complicated, it's literally the same as it was before big file support as long as you don't use the big files.

Thanks for ignoring that I already addressed your complaint in the post you respond to. Read my post again, to the END.

" it's literally the same as it was before big file support as long as you don't use the big files. " Yes, and I attack this status quo.

> [krixano](#comment_110_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): Why would you have to manage the missing big files? You don't need those big files on every device you use. If you want just necessary files, then don't use big files. It doesn't make it more complicated, it's literally the same as it was before big file support as long as you don't use the big files.  [...]

Because this way ZeroNet will always assume on each other device that something is _"missing"_ even though it is actually just a optional only thing that of course is not put on every device. It's about keeping clean structures, since this directory way of doing it is not really natively modular.

> [krixano](#comment_112_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): How does it assume it's missing?

How does it not?

> [krixano](#comment_113_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): Reply


That's the problem I want to avoid.
It should be obvious to you that a simple question is not an argument......

> [krixano](#comment_114_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): However, if you are talking about the fact that it assumes that the file will be the same name in the same location, then that is the real problem you should be talking about, and can be fixed.

This might be part of the problem. I would be totally okay with a structure like the following (very roughly):
ZeroNet/ - for our good old beloved 0N
0files/ - in the same directory as the ZeroNet folder; only holds the files to share; if you use ZeroNet on another device then ZeroNet just checks if the folder exists and if not just ignores further actions or assumptions; if there are different folders within _0files_ then ZeroNet explicitly just checks if the folders exist, if they do not, ZeroNet again stops working on this topic at all

> [krixano](#comment_115_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): Here's the thing:You say you want a slim ZeroNet where you don't have to have big files [...]

I was responding to your simple question with a mirror.
I agree with everything except "Don't use big files on devices that you don't need them on".
It maybe _"works"_ same as communism _"worked"_. It is possible, but it's not clean, at all. That's my problem. I want ZeroNet to stay like a fresh baby butt after bathing.

> [krixano](#comment_117_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): Also, I asked the question based on what you said because I didn't understand what you were meaning. Typically, when someone responds with the opposite of the question as a question (like you did), it means that they think it's obvious that it is not worth explaining, and try to use it as an argument by prompting the other person to think about what they think is obvious - otherwise they would have just answered the question in the first place.

No, it's fine.

> [krixano](#comment_116_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): How exactly is it not clean? Those files aren't getting downloaded, obviously.

It's not clean because something in ZeroNet's body is "missing" even though it is optional. I just wish for a clearer distinction between necessary ZeroNet organs, basic zites one saved and big files you will have on way fewer devices.

1509129499_17H8EGEoNF1z2AXFtXmBQJLHTmh7g.body:
I'm a YouTube power user since it came out, so I still remember the 5 star system from back then. After all these years of experience and many thoughts about it, I would be fine with a Like / Neutral / Dislike system. Because not every video I don't like is bad and vice versa. 

And to your opinion on the dislikes: I thought the same way some time ago. Until I realized that this system is the only one that makes sense after all. Because if we are honest, we realize that people, especially the average person, will vote with how much they like or dislike what they experienced, in mind. We can't expect the user to be a professional judge and judge it by how "good" the video is based on objective reasons and not their subjective ones. Therefore I think it is justified, that the like/dislike system exists in this way. Although, as previously mentioned, I would personally add a _neutral_ button, as well.
That said, what is wrong about mass-disliking? It still reflects the truth. The truth, that a _massive_ amount of people don't like this video. E.g. videos about people liking Hitler are mass disliked and that's good! Same with the trans- and black hitlers on YouTube nowadays.

Regarding your last paragraph, I don't think that everyone has the ability to seed all their liked videos, when they wish to. Additionally, we can still solve the "I think this video might be bad, because I saw that it is already disliked by a lot of people~"-bias easily by letting the user see the like/dislike ratio only AFTER they voted already, as well.

> [realkittykate](#comment_45_17H8EGEoNF1z2AXFtXmBQJLHTmh7gMGzzS): Of course, the problem with mass-disliking is that a lot of them create fake accounts in order to achieve this. And true, not everybody has the disk space required in order to be a dedicated seeder. . . [...]

Really? How many phone numbers will someone waste for so many "fake accounts"?

"Kill all muslims" is clearly extremist, which excludes that it could be "alt-right". (Btw. it's not even nazi, because Hitler didn't hate muslims.)

I count all the Chinese threads in the English main forum as trolling to some extent.

Other than that, I agree.

Depends on what you mean by "Linux-like". If you mean, you want a literal Linux Desktop like usually on your computer, then you can emulate e.g. Debian, Backbox or other OSes.

If you mean OSes for smartphones that are **based on Linux** then there are some to choose from:
* Android
* Ubuntu Mobile
* webOS
* Sailfish OS
* Firefox OS
* Amazon Fire OS
* Copperhead OS
* Tizen

As you will see once you check each OS out, basically all alternatives to Android are either obsoleted/abandoned or have still today many restrictions, mostly in regards to the hardware they depend on. E.g. Copperhead OS is supposed to be a "security focused" OS while it only works on cheap Chinese smartphones that have of course no tracking hardware in them, at all. ;)

1509518161_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
> [combo](#comment_1_13Zi5FudifjZ6ksrVtDpRVCwpF5UPiBGdD): A user rated system would be nice as well. For example when a site is blacklisted by (choose a number) users, you would get a prompt warning you as what content is contained.

I think that is utterly useless, because this way almost every zite would get a prompt and after confirming 3 prompts in a row, everyone would just confirm every prompt.

> [phr34kzz](#comment_20_166Kgk6LesoTpoTTWciSHeq98UB4mTUcsf): I'm only saying that it's a good idea, but there's loop holes. As it is, people can already hijack other zites by making a new zite, rename it to some other non obstructive zite with the same name and use the same tags. Theoretically, that's the same as "Phishing" if you get my jazz.  Maybe work on those weaknesses before implementing more features. My guess is not many here are as tech savvy to tell between urls and what they clicking aside from a nice zite title?

Speaking of that, I think  that before we continue to add more and more and more features to the client we should first eliminate as many problems as we can that are already existing within the borders of the client's current functionality. Right now we should stop adding any new major features and fix bugs, then improve the core elements and finally polish them. Once that is done we can consider progressing in regards to new features, again.

@styromaniac regarding OP: I understand where these concerns are coming from, but on the other hand I partially see an ill-fitting intent in your request. As I understand, ZeroNet is a network of freedom for everyone. Why would anyone looking for this freedom want to be constrained by their stupid local laws? (To not heat up the discussion too crazily, let's leave out child porn, snuff vids, etc. out of this argument, for now.)
I'm sure that most of ZeroNet users have a really good reason to be here and not on just any platform on the clearnet. That's why I'm also sure that most readers here understand what I mean by saying that the confirmation bias + other biases get tunneled and emphasized more each time someone uses e.g. facebook or twitter. People see what they want to see, what they _think_ they choose (but don't really) to experience. I don't want to see ZeroNet having features cross the line from "filtering" by own volition to "tunneling" the user into his space without (or with only little control). Yes, of course this is a little overexaggerated, but you get the point. Even only a little step in this direction might be a bad decision for this platform made for the people, if not done carefully and the right way.

Therefore my answer to people living for e.g. under French law looking out to avoid lolicon: it's their own job to filter their zearches properly and to check proxies for their viability. To me, the best thing we could do to help those people is increase transparency so more people can understand and know more about the zite's/proxy's or whatever's intention and state. Because as is clear to everyone, knowledge is power. It makes people powerful and gives them the ability to use their freedom wisely. According to a famous philosopher true freedom is only achievable if the user of it has enough knowledge to be able to use it, in the first place.

So especially regarding your suggestions about something like an automated system that filters something automatically: I think that should not be our way, the way of ZeroNet. In that case I rather imagine e.g. a zearch result page with showing every (zite) link with the correct tags that maybe can be assigned to, like in Steam. If the user looking at the result thinks "nope, no lolicon for me" then he should be able to see the tag and avoid entering the zite. Or if the zearch has a filtering function then the user should filter the tags for each search or write a script or we could implement a zearch profile, that saves the filter preference in a simple file, so the user doesn't have to filter before each zearch. But all these "automated" things should be accessible only through the frontend and not on the "backend" (metaphorically). (Backend = implemented into client -> hard to change by an average non-developer user) Although, even if the user would be able to easily change between automated moderation or not then it still would be too much hardcore filtering. My hard to explain point is that every user of this platform should be kind of easily exposed to any _anormal_ content (not including gruesome, that's another hour-long debate) even if they don't actively "choose" to experience it. Freedom of expression only works if we protect people who express opinions that are in minorities. The people of the most popular opinion have the job of making sure that everyone has a voice and everyone can be heard, no matter what opinion they have. Letting these people only express their opinions in a way that nobody can hear it, because it's all filtered out (automatically?) then the whole point is already dead.

As I partially pointed out, I think a Steam-like tag system would be great. People can assign their own tags to any zite and the more often a specific tag got independently assigned by many different peers, the higher up it will be seen in the tag list. If at some point some morons would still emerge from the scam-depths of the clearnet by making tons of accounts and faking the tags, then we could still "blacklist" it publicly on a dedicated topic post in 0list, that everyone should subscribe to, to follow the newly added zites.
